user_message:
Target function code is:
```c
static bool
get_nonce_timestamp (const char *const nonce,
                     size_t noncelen,
                     uint64_t *const ptimestamp)
{
  if (0 == noncelen)
    noncelen = strlen (nonce);

  if (true
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#if defined(MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT) || defined(MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT)
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
      )
    return false;

  if (TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN !=
      MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (nonce + noncelen - TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             ptimestamp))
    return false;
  return true;
}
```

List additional symbols that are required to analyze the target function to determine if the target function code violates the following MISRA C rule:
A for loop shall be well-formed. The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
The list will be included in the prompt for the next agent, so be concise and clear.
Explain why each symbol is required in the analysis of the target function for the MISRA C rule.
explanation: - MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_: This function is the direct callee inside get_nonce_timestamp and does the substring-to-uint64 conversion. Any for-loops it contains (loop counters, loop control flags, side effects in clauses, or modification of non-counter objects) must be inspected to decide MISRA conformance for the target call chain.\n- toxdigitvalue: It is called by MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_. If MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ uses for-loops that call this helper (or this helper itself contains loops), those loops must be examined for well-formedness and for illegal modifications of objects used by the for-loop body.\n- strlen: Called by get_nonce_timestamp when noncelen is zero. Although it is a library routine, its implementation may contain for-loops; because the MISRA rule requires examining the behaviour of functions invoked by the target function, strlen should be available to verify any for-loops it contains.
